items.title: Calgary emergency wards coping with 'extreme overcapacity' in flu season: AHS memo
items.summary_auto: Hospitals are tightening policies to prevent patient bottlenecks, even if beds aren't available, according to a memo obtained by CBC News.

items.title: EU, France condemn U.S. visa ban targeting former EU commissioner, activists
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration on Tuesday imposed visa bans on a former European Union commissioner and anti-disinformation campaigners it says were involved in censoring U.S. social media platforms, in the latest move in a campaign aimed at European rules that U.S. officials say go beyond legitimate regulation.

items.title: Yukoners prepare for power outages as temperatures continue to dip into -40s
U.S., Ukraine reach consensus on key issues to end war, but territorial disputes remain
items.summary_auto: The United States and Ukraine have reached a consensus on several critical issues aimed at bringing an end to the nearly four-year conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but sensitive issues around territorial control and managing its nuclear plant remain unresolved, Zelenskyy told journalists on Tuesday.

items.title: Regina Transition House opens Santa’s workshop for families fleeing violence
items.summary_auto: Women and children staying at Regina Transition House now have access to Santa’s workshop — a safe space where mothers can choose Christmas gifts for their children.

items.title: U.S. alcohol group takes aim at markup on local spirits in N.S.
items.summary_auto: The organization that represents some of America's largest spirits producers is calling for the NSLC to remove a policy that gives preferential markup to Nova Scotian spirit products.

items.title: Sir John A. Macdonald was erased from some public spaces. Now there's a movement to bring him back
items.summary_auto: The racial reckoning of the COVID era saw Canada grapple with its checkered past — a process that led to statues of some foundational figures being removed, in some instances by force. Five years on, there's a growing movement to restore some of what was taken down in that tumultuous period.

items.title: This ain't your parents' Game Boy: New gaming handhelds are powerful, pricey — and far from pocket-sized
items.summary_auto: This year marks the first time all three major gaming hardware companies — Nintendo, Sony and Microsoft — have handheld devices on the market. But they're all very different. Which one is right for you?

items.title: The Elf on the Shelf has been delightful and divisive for 20 years. Here's how we got here
items.summary_auto: Twenty years after it was introduced to the world by Carol Aebersold and her daughter Chanda Bell, the Elf on the Shelf is now a staple of modern Christmas festivities, having become a cherished tradition for kids and a creative headache for parents.

items.title: Everyone's obsessed with Heated Rivalry. Could it change how we see gay sex on screen?
items.summary_auto: Fans and critics say Heated Rivalry is reminiscent of titles like Queer as Folk and The L Word, which were some of the first to depict same-sex intimacy on the small screen. They hope the Canadian show might break the mould in new ways.

items.title: He opened a Christmas store in the summer of 1986. It's been Santa, stockings and ornaments ever since
items.summary_auto: When Marc Gaboury decided to start a business of his own in 1986, he felt it was obvious Quebec City's tourist district needed a year-round Christmas store. It has been a mainstay ever since.

items.title: Venezuelan parliament moves to criminalize seizure of oil tankers as Trump ramps up pressure on Maduro
items.summary_auto: Venezuela's parliament on Tuesday approved a measure that criminalizes a broad range of activities that can hinder navigation and commerce in the South American country, such as the seizure of oil tankers.

items.title: American billionaire wins defamation lawsuit against Peter Nygard
items.summary_auto: Billionaire hedge fund manager Louis Bacon has won his long-running defamation lawsuit alleging that former fashion mogul and convicted sex offender Peter Nygard spread lies about him during a public spat over their adjacent properties in the Bahamas.

items.title: Mother grieves after 11-year-old son killed by carbon monoxide poisoning, husband in hospital
items.summary_auto: Marina Hills's son Henry Losco died on Dec. 19 in their apartment at 1827 Albert St., after carbon monoxide spread leaked in the building while maintenance work was being done. Her husband Sergio Losco survived but is still in hospital.

items.title: 11-year-old boy from Newfoundland killed by carbon monoxide poisoning in Regina
items.summary_auto: Marina Hills's son Henry Losco died on Dec. 19 in their apartment at 1827 Albert St., after carbon monoxide spread leaked in the building while maintenance work was being done. Her husband Sergio Losco survived but is still in hospital.

items.title: It's so cold in the Yukon, the power grid can't keep up
items.summary_auto: Frigid temperatures that hover around -40 C — or -50 C in some communities — continue to keep much of the territory in their grip. There’s no sign of that weather, patterns of which are coming from Siberia, easing up any time soon.

items.title: Parkland school shooting survivor confronts trauma again during Brown University shooting
items.summary_auto: It’s rare for anyone to say they’ve lived through one mass shooting, let alone two. But at just 20 years old, Zoe Weissman now belongs to a growing club that no one would ever choose to join. The sophomore says she was in her dorm room on Brown University’s campus Dec. 13, when she got a frantic phone call from a friend. Weissman says she suspected right away that there’d been a shooting.

items.title: 2025: The sports year in pictures
items.summary_auto: From the bloody good 4 Nations Face-Off to the Blue Jays' thrilling World Series run, here's a look at the athletes and moments that shaped the past 12 months.

items.title: Ashley MacIsaac concert cancelled after AI wrongly accuses him of being sex offender
items.summary_auto: Cape Breton fiddler Ashley MacIsaac says he may have been defamed by Google after it recently produced an AI-generated summary falsely identifying him as a sex offender.

items.title: Carney says public service part of 'sacrifices' to be made
items.summary_auto: CBC News chief political correspondent Rosemary Barton sat down with the prime minister for a year-end interview, in which she asked him about his previous comments that Canadians will be expected to make sacrifices.

items.title: U.K. police drop probe into Bob Vylan comments about Israeli military
items.summary_auto: British police had been investigating comments by the rap duo Bob Vylan, which included an on-stage chant of "death, death to the IDF," made at the Glastonbury music festival in June. Police concluded on Tuesday that the comments did not meet the threshold for criminal prosecution.

items.title: P.E.I. man charged with hate crimes in what police say is a 1st for the island
items.summary_auto: A 25-year-old Prince Edward Island man faces charges related to promoting hatred and antisemitism — charges the RCMP says are a first in the province.

items.title: Norwegian biathlete dies at 27 during Olympic training camp in Italy
items.summary_auto: Norwegian biathlon Olympic hopeful Sivert Guttorm Bakken has died suddenly. He was 27.

items.title: Quebec approves roadwork in rare forest under review for protected status
items.summary_auto: Tensions are mounting in Quebec’s Mauricie region as citizens, environmental groups and scientists push back against provincially approved forestry roadwork in a rare old-growth forest near Sainte-Thècle.

items.title: Immersive show illuminates 800-year-old cathedral in Brussels
items.summary_auto: The Cathedral of Saint Michael and Saint Gudula in Belgium's capital is celebrating its 800th anniversary in 2026. The festivities include a one-hour immersive light show that combines 360-degree video mapping and live music.
